title: Connor McDavid scores first NHL goal in losing effort Hockey | Sports | Toront
text:
DALLAS — The franchise player made a little history.
And the Edmonton Oilers made a big mess.
Connor McDavid scored his first NHL goal of his NHL career and Anders Nilsson delivered a goaltending performance for the ages Tuesday night in Dallas, but it wasn’t enough to overcome everything else.
“We weren’t in that game,” a visibly disturbed head coach Todd McLellan said after a 4-2 loss that should have been 8-2.
“The other two (losses) we showed up at the rink and we were prepared, we were ready to engage. I thought tonight we were just putting time in. We weren’t ready to push. We were happy to defend. We let them bring the game to us.”
And so the Oilers are 0-3, spoiling what was supposed to be a great moment for the kid and wasting a sensational effort from Nilsson, who deserved to walk out of the American Airlines Center with a win.
Not that the Oilers, who were outshot 52-27, deserved a win, but it would have been nice.
“Congratulations to Connor, it’s something he’s been waiting his whole life for, and Nilly played great for us between the posts,” said Oilers winger Matt Hendricks. “But as a group we have to look in the mirror because we gave them 40 minutes of hockey for free.
“Those first 40 minutes … there’s no excuse for that.”
McLellan didn’t like a lot of key areas of his team, like the Taylor Hall, Ryan Nugent-Hopkins line and a lot of his defence, which is kind of disheartening in the third game of the season when the team was already 0-2.
“I think we’re a better team that we showed,” he said. “We had some key people who weren’t engaged in the game and we had others who were overwhelmed in the game and that’s the result we’re going to get when that happens.
“I wasn’t disappointed in St. Louis or Nashville with their approach to the game, I thought they gave us what they had, but I don’t believe that happened tonight.”
But, hey, McDavid scored, which turned out to be the highlight of the road trip.
After five pre-season games and two regular season games without a goal, he finally has his first of many.
“It’s something pretty special, something I’ll remember for the rest of my life,” said McDavid. “Obviously not the way you want to end that game, but pretty special to get it out of the way.
“I was excited, but a lot of it was relief, just with the pressure there is these days. It felt good.”
But McDavid was quick to point out that he won’t be leaving Dallas feeling any sort of good about the way Tuesday night went, or this whole trip went, for that matter.
“It’s not about me at all,” he said. “It’s about the team, and this was a very disappointing road trip.”
Nilsson kept the Oilers alive through their brutal start, limiting the damage to 2-0 on goals from Jason Spezza (on the Stars 16th shot of the first period) and Jamie Benn early in the second.
The McDavid line fought back, however, scoring on back to back shifts.
Oscar Klefbom got it going with a point shot that deflected in off of Vern Fiddler at 10:55 and McDavid tied it with a deflection of his own, on Andrej Sekera’s point shot at 12:18.
This one had loss written on it from the start, though, and the end came when Spezza put a wrist shot through Nilsson’s five hole at 15:30 of the third period, on Dallas’s 48th shot.
Spezza completed his hat-trick with an empty netter, and Nilsson has to walk away with a loss.
“Anders made some tremendous saves,” said McLellan. “On one or two goals he’s like to have them back but I don’t know how you can be disappointed in his performance.”

GAME REVIEW
Stars 4, Oilers 2
THREE STARS
Jason Spezza ,DAL - Scores the first, third and fourth Dallas goals in the win
Anders Nilsson , EDM - He was a brick wall when the embattled Oilers needed one
Jamie Benn , DAL - Delivers a strong game and scores a nice goal for Dallas
GAME GRADES
GAME D
Offence C
Defence D
Goaltending A
Power Play C
Penalty Killing A
Toughness B
Effort B
WHY THEY LOST
Because they showed up late and their defensive shortcomings resulted in long, drawn out periods spent under siege. This one should have been a blowout loss, but Nilsson kept them alive.
HALL DRAWS IN
Taylor Hall fell ill Monday night, missed the morning skate Tuesday and was listed as questionable for the game with Dallas, but he took the pre-game skate and declared himself good to go.
HOME OPENER
After starting the season with three tough games on the road, the Oilers finally got to play in front of some friendly faces when they play their home opener nine days into the season.
NEXT UP
Thursday vs St. Louis
